title: Project Sample A
description: An exploration of cetacean species richness on the California coast.
contents:
Show code

# Read in the data all together
species <- here("data","ca_cetaceans", "ca_cetaceans")
species_files <- dir(species, full.names = TRUE, pattern = "*.tif")

# Rasterize all these files together using raster::stack
cetaceans_data <- raster::stack(species_files)

# Write a function to determine if species are present in a cell, with a threshold of 0.6 meaning "present"
is_present <- function(x, thresh = .6){
  y <- ifelse(x >= thresh, 1, 0)
  return(y)
}

# Apply the threshold function to our stack
species_richness <- calc(cetaceans_data, fun = is_present)

# Find out how many species are in each cell
species_richness1 <- calc(species_richness, fun = sum, na.rm = TRUE)





Show code

# Now create the file to use for the CA coastline

states <- ne_download(scale = 110, type = "states", category = "cultural", returnclass = "sf")

ca_state <- states %>% 
  filter(name == "California")





Show code

# Crop the species raster to match the CA coastline
species_raster_cropped <- crop(species_richness1, extent(ca_state))

# Now turn this cropped raster into a dataframe
species_richness_df <- raster::rasterToPoints(species_raster_cropped) %>%
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  filter(layer != 0) # Filter out cells that have no data in them

# Now we have the species richness dataframe with which to make our ggplot!





Show code

# Now plot everything together

ggplot()+
  geom_raster(data = species_richness_df, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = layer))+
  geom_sf(data = ca_state, fill = "lemonchiffon2")+
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "mediumblue", name = "Likely number of cetacean species present")+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "grey90"))+
  labs( x = "Longitude",
        y = "Latitude",
        title = "Cetacean species richness on the California coast")




Figure 1: Map of species richness of cetaceans off the coast of California. Species richness is defined as the number of species likely to be present in a certain area. For a species to be considered “present,” a likelihood threshold of 0.6 was observed, meaning that there had to be a minimum 60% chance that a species would be present in order for it to be considered “present” in our analysis.
Note: I purposely did not clip the extent of the map because I liked the aesthetics of seeing the whole state shape rather than just the extent covered by the species raster. To clip I would have inserted a line in my ggplot of coord_sf(xlim = c(-125, -115), ylim = c(32, 38)).
Sources:
Kaschner, K., Rius-Barile, J., Kesner-Reyes, K., Garilao, C., Kullander, S., Rees, T., & Froese, R. (2016). AquaMaps: Predicted range maps for aquatic species. www.aquamaps.org
Made with Natural Earth. Free vector and raster map data @ naturalearthdata.com.
End Project Sample A

title: Project Sample B
description: Using binary logistic regression to test the feasibility of using plant height, canopy length, canopy width, and number of green leaves to determine species of palmetto.
contents:
hide

# Read in data

palmetto_data <- read_csv(here("data", "palmetto.csv"), 
                          col_types = cols(.default = 'c')) %>% 
  mutate(height = as.numeric(height)) %>% 
  mutate(length = as.numeric(length)) %>% 
  mutate(width = as.numeric(width)) %>% 
  mutate(green_lvs = as.numeric(green_lvs))



Overview
This report evaluates data on two palmetto species, and uses binary logistic regression to test the feasibility of using certain indicator variables (tree height, canopy length, canopy width, and number of green leaves) to determine the trees’ species. Species 1 represents Serenoa repens, while Species 2 represents Sabal etonia. For the purposes of this analysis, I will be simply referring to them as “Species 1” and “Species 2” respectively unless stated otherwise.
Data source: Abrahamson, W.G. 2019. Survival, growth and biomass estimates of two dominant palmetto species of south-central Florida from 1981 - 2017, ongoing at 5-year intervals ver 1. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/f2f96ec76fbbd4b9db431c79a770c4d5
Results
1. Exploratory Visualizations
Principle Components Analysis (PCA)


hide

# Make PCA subset

palmetto_pca <- palmetto_data %>% 
  select(height, length, width, green_lvs) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  scale() %>% 
  prcomp()

# Make another subset for labeling
palmetto_complete <- palmetto_data %>% 
  drop_na(height, length, width, green_lvs)

# Make PCA biplot

autoplot(palmetto_pca,
         data = palmetto_complete,
         colour = "species",
         size = 1,
         alpha = 0.7,
         loadings = TRUE,
         loadings.label = TRUE)+
  scale_color_manual(values = c("goldenrod", "forestgreen"))+
  theme_bw()




Figure 1: PCA biplot of our palmetto data. Principle component 1 (PC1) accounts for ~69% of variance in our data, and principle component 2 (PC2) accounts for ~20% of the variance in our data.
Key takeaways:
From our biplot, we can see the number of green leaves on a tree and the length of canopy have almost no correlation, as their loadings are at approximately 90 degrees to each other.
Tree height, canopy width, and canopy length all appear to be closely (positively) correlated, as they are loaded closely together.
Additionally, it appears the two species begin to diverge in similarity along increasing PC1.
Tree Height vs. Canopy Length


hide

# Other dataviz

ggplot(data = palmetto_data, aes(x = length, y = height))+
  geom_point(aes(color=species), alpha = 0.7)+
  scale_color_manual(values = c("goldenrod", "forestgreen"))+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Canopy Length",
       y = "Height")




Figure 2: Height of trees vs. canopy length.
Key takeaways:
We can see that in both species, canopy length generally increases with increasing tree height.
However, Species 2 seems to tend to have a lower height overall.
2. Binary Logistic Regression
Variables:
Tree height (cm)
Canopy length (cm)
Canopy width(cm)
Number of green leaves
For this evaluation, our “0” reference level is Species 1, or Serenoa repens. Since a binary logistic regression calculates the probability of the non-zero factor, this indicates that our output will evaluate the probability that an observation is Species 2, or Sabal etonia.


hide

# Make a subset with our species numbers as factors. 

palmetto_blr_data <- palmetto_complete %>% 
  mutate(species = as.factor(species))

# Double check the factor levels, and we see that "Species 1" is our 0 reference level. So left-hand side of equation will be probability of SPECIES 2.

palmetto_blr <- glm(species ~ height + length + width + green_lvs,
                    data = palmetto_blr_data,
                    family = "binomial")

tidy_palmetto_blr <- broom::tidy(palmetto_blr)

final_palmetto_blr <- tidy_palmetto_blr %>% 
  mutate(p.value=case_when(p.value <= 0.0001 ~ "<0.0001"))

kbl(
  final_palmetto_blr,
  col.names = c("Predictor Variable", "Coefficient", "Std. Error", "Statistic", "p-value"),
  align = c("l", "c", "c", "c", "c"),
   digits = 3,
  caption = "Table 1: Results of binary linear regression on palmetto data.") %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped",
                full_width = F)



Table 1: Table 1: Results of binary linear regression on palmetto data.


Predictor Variable


Coefficient


Std. Error


Statistic


p-value


(Intercept)


3.227


0.142


22.712


<0.0001


height


-0.029


0.002


-12.670


<0.0001


length


0.046


0.002


24.556


<0.0001


width


0.039


0.002


18.782


<0.0001


green_lvs


-1.908


0.039


-49.107


<0.0001


3. Success of Regression Model


hide

# What are the actual probabilities of being Species 2 for each of the existing observations in our palmetto_complete data frame?

# Create the fitted blr - probability that an observation is Species 2.

blr_fitted <- palmetto_blr %>% 
  broom::augment(type.predict = "response")

# Wrangle this dataset into something usable for an output

blr_correct <- blr_fitted %>% 
  mutate(predicted = case_when(.fitted >= 0.50 ~ 2,
                               .fitted <= 0.50 ~ 1)) %>% 
  mutate(correct = case_when(predicted == species ~ "Correct",
                             TRUE ~ "Incorrect")) %>% 
  mutate(species = case_when(species == 1 ~ "Serenoa repens",
                             species == 2 ~ "Sabal etonia")) %>%
  select(species, .fitted, predicted, correct) %>% 
  group_by(species, correct) %>% 
  summarize(number_correct = n()) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = correct, values_from = number_correct) %>%
  mutate(Percent_Correct = (Correct/(Incorrect+Correct)*100))

# Now make it pretty!

kbl(
  blr_correct,
  col.names = c("Species", "Correctly Classified", "Incorrectly Classified", "Percent Correctly Classified"),
  digits = 3,
  align = c("l", "c", "c", "c"),
  caption =  "Table 2: Successful prediction of species by binary linear regression on palmetto data.") %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped",
                full_width = F) 



Table 2: Table 2: Successful prediction of species by binary linear regression on palmetto data.


Species


Correctly Classified


Incorrectly Classified


Percent Correctly Classified


Sabal etonia


5701


454


92.624


Serenoa repens


5548


564


90.772

title: Project Sample C
description: Using multicriteria analysis (MCA) to determine priority watersheds for conservation in southern Santa Barbara County.
contents: Using MCA to determine priority watersheds for conservation

title: Project Sample D
description: Principle components analysis (PCA) of nutritional values of breakfast cereals.
contents:
Introduction
This analysis examines the relationships between major nutritional values of breakfast cereals produced by major manufacturers General Mills Inc., Kellogg Co., Post Foods LLC, and the Quaker Oats Co. These manufacturers were chosen as they are the largest producers of breakfast cereals by sales. Nutritional data is provided by the USDA FoodData Central. The major nutritional values explored are kcal, protein, fat, carbs, sugar, and fiber content, in accordance with FDA guidance.
Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/index.html
Wrangling and PCA
1. Wrangle data


# Read in the data we're using, then clean it up a bit.

usda_nutrients <- read.csv(here("data", "usda_nutrients.csv")) %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  mutate(across(where(is.character), tolower))

# Create a subset of only the data we will be using - in this case, breakfast cereals. We will be comparing the major nutrient values: kcal, protein, carbs, fat, sugar and fiber.

cereals_nutrients <- usda_nutrients %>% 
  filter(food_group == "breakfast cereals") %>% # Select for breakfast cereals.
  filter(mfg_name %in% c("kellogg, co.", "the quaker oats, co.", "general mills inc.", "post foods, llc")) # Select specifically for the four brands we are evaluating. 



2. PCA


# Now write the code for PCA with the dataset we created above.

cereals_pca <- cereals_nutrients %>% # Create a pca dataset starting with the cereals subset we created above.
  select(energy_kcal, ends_with("_g")) %>% # Select the variables we will be performing PCA for
  drop_na() %>% # Drop any NA values 
  scale() %>% # Scale the values, since they are not all measured in the same units
  prcomp() # Principle components

cereals_complete <- cereals_nutrients %>% 
  drop_na(energy_kcal, ends_with("_g")) # Create a dataset to pull from, then drop observations with NA for our variables of interest.

autoplot(cereals_pca,
         data = cereals_complete, # Use this dataset to create aesthetics
         colour = 'mfg_name',
         loadings = TRUE, # Add loadings arrows
         loadings.label = TRUE,
         loadings.colour = "black",
         loadings.label.colour = "black",
         loadings.label.vjust = -0.5)+
  theme_minimal()+
  scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0.05,0.05))+ # Expand limits so we can read the arrow labels
  scale_color_manual(labels = c("General Mills", "Kellogg", "Post Foods", "Quaker Oats"), values = c("cornflowerblue", "coral", "forestgreen", "darkblue"))+
  labs(colour = "Manufacturer")




Figure 1: Biplot depicting principle component analysis (PCA) of six different nutritional variables among breakfast cereals produced by four different manufacturers.
Summary
From the above Principle Component Analysis and biplot, we can draw the following takeaways:
Fiber and protein content appear most closely correlated, as these arrows are closest together, thus indicating that the variance explained by these variables are similar.
Sugar and fiber content have a negative correlation in breakfast cereals, as the angle between their arrows is much larger than 90 degrees and thus nearly opposite.
Protein and fiber content have a slight negative loading value on Principle Component 1 (PC1), while fat, kcal, carb and sugar content all have a positive loading value on PC1.
Sugar content has the only positive loading value on Principle Component 2 (PC2), while all other variables have a negative loading value on PC2.
However, upon adding the variances explained by PC1 and PC2, we see that this biplot only explains approximately 61.75% of variance among the data we are evaluating. This indicates that further analysis and consideration is needed to confidently evaluate correlation between variables in this data set.
